title: Trailer, tickets for 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' to be released today - San Antonio Express-News

Image 1 of 66 Think you know everything about "Star Wars?"
Scroll through the slideshow for 30 facts to test your knowledge about the iconic fantasy franchise.
Think you know everything about "Star Wars?"
Scroll through the slideshow for 30 facts to test your knowledge about the iconic fantasy franchise.
Image 2 of 66 1. Tupac Shakur apparently read for the role of Mace Windu in "The Phantom Menace" before he died in September 1996, according to former Death Row Records engineer Rick Clifford. The part went to Samuel L. Jackson.
Source: Rolling Stone 1. Tupac Shakur apparently read for the role of Mace Windu in "The Phantom Menace" before he died in September 1996, according to former Death Row Records engineer Rick Clifford. The part went to Samuel L. ... more Image 3 of 66 2. Samuel L. Jackson claims that his character Mace Windu in the "Star Wars" prequel trilogy has the words "bad m r" carved into his purple lightsaber, recalling the inscription on Jules Winnfield's wallet in "Pulp Fiction."
Source: BBC/YouTube 2. Samuel L. Jackson claims that his character Mace Windu in the "Star Wars" prequel trilogy has the words "bad m r" carved into his purple lightsaber, recalling the inscription on Jules ... more Photo: File/Lucasfilm/Getty Images Image 4 of 66 3. At the behest of his daughters, George Lucas filmed an NSYNC cameo for "Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones." He later cut the scene.
Source: MTV 3. At the behest of his daughters, George Lucas filmed an NSYNC cameo for "Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones." He later cut the scene.
Source: MTV Photo: Jeff Kravitz, FilmMagic Image 5 of 66 4. Carrie Fisher complained that her costumes in the first two films weren't sexy enough. In response, costume designers crafted the infamous "slave bikini" used during the Jabba the Hutt sequence in "Return of the Jedi."
Source: The FW 4. Carrie Fisher complained that her costumes in the first two films weren't sexy enough. In response, costume designers crafted the infamous "slave bikini" used during the Jabba the Hutt sequence in ... more Photo: Courtesy Photo Image 6 of 66 5. Han Solo's a bit of a cradle robber. Harrison Ford was 37 years old when "The Empire Strikes Back," which features the famous romance between Han Solo and Princess Leia, hit theaters May 21, 1980.
Carrie Fisher's age at the time? 23. 5. Han Solo's a bit of a cradle robber. Harrison Ford was 37 years old when "The Empire Strikes Back," which features the famous romance between Han Solo and Princess Leia, hit theaters May 21, ... more Photo: Handout, McClatchy-Tribune News Service Image 7 of 66 6. Chewbacca's distinctive voice is a mix of bears, lions, walruses and badgers among other dying animals.
Source: Mashable 6. Chewbacca's distinctive voice is a mix of bears, lions, walruses and badgers among other dying animals.
Source: Mashable Photo: handout CD Image 8 of 66 7. Despite its groundbreaking special effects and wide vistas, the first "Star Wars" film was made on a meager budget of $11 million.
In today's dollars, that's a bit more than $46 million. For some perspective, the effects-heavy 2012 movie "The Avengers" cost $220 million to make.
Source: Box Office Mojo / U.S. Inflation Calculator 7. Despite its groundbreaking special effects and wide vistas, the first "Star Wars" film was made on a meager budget of $11 million.
In today's dollars, that's a bit more than $46 million. For some... Photo: File Image 9 of 66 8. When handmaiden Padmé and Queen Amidala — both played by Natalie Portman — appear together in scenes in "The Phantom Menace," Portman portrays Padmé while a young Keira Knightley plays a handmaiden disguised as Amidala.
Source: iMDB 8. When handmaiden Padmé and Queen Amidala — both played by Natalie Portman — appear together in scenes in "The Phantom Menace," Portman portrays Padmé while a young Keira Knightley plays a handmaiden ... more Photo: File Image 10 of 66 9. Yoda, the wise Jedi master, was almost played by a monkey carrying a cane and wearing a mask in "The Empire Strikes Back."
Source: The Wrap 9. Yoda, the wise Jedi master, was almost played by a monkey carrying a cane and wearing a mask in "The Empire Strikes Back."
Source: The Wrap Photo: 1996-98 AccuSoft Inc. Image 11 of 66 10. Harrison Ford received only $10,000 for his performance as Han Solo in "Star Wars," later renamed "Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope."
Source: TheRichest 10. Harrison Ford received only $10,000 for his performance as Han Solo in "Star Wars," later renamed "Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope."
Source: TheRichest Image 12 of 66 11. While filming "The Phantom Menace," Ewan McGregor kept making the iconic lightsaber sound while filming fight sequences, despite the fact that George Lucas explained to him that the sounds would be added in during post-production.
McGregor's explanation? "I keep getting carried away."
Source: iMDB 11. While filming "The Phantom Menace," Ewan McGregor kept making the iconic lightsaber sound while filming fight sequences, despite the fact that George Lucas explained to him that the sounds would be ... more Photo: File/Lucasfilm Image 13 of 66 12. George Lucas got the name for the adorable droid R2-D2 while working on his 1973 movie "American Graffiti." Sound editor Walter Murch asked for "R2-D2, the abbreviation for "reel two, dialogue track two." Lucas apparently lurched up, asked Murch to repeat himself and said, "What a great name!"
Source: Film Freak Central 12. George Lucas got the name for the adorable droid R2-D2 while working on his 1973 movie "American Graffiti." Sound editor Walter Murch asked for "R2-D2, the abbreviation for "reel two, dialogue track ... more Photo: File/Getty Images Image 14 of 66 13. Researchers believe that Anakin Skywalker — who murders countless children and aliens and chokes out his pregnant wife — meets at least six of the nine criteria for borderline personality disorder.
Source: LiveScience 13. Researchers believe that Anakin Skywalker — who murders countless children and aliens and chokes out his pregnant wife — meets at least six of the nine criteria for borderline personality ... more Image 15 of 66 14. The alien E.T. from Steven Spielberg's 1982 movie "E.T. the Extra Terrestrial" make a slight cameo in "The Phantom Menace" where three similar aliens appear in the Galactic Senate.
The characters' appearance is not intended to imply a connection between the two films, but is the result of an arrangement between Spielberg and George Lucas by which the alien would be included in Lucas' next "Star Wars" movie after Yoda appeared in "E.T."
Source: Star Wars Wikia 14. The alien E.T. from Steven Spielberg's 1982 movie "E.T. the Extra Terrestrial" make a slight cameo in "The Phantom Menace" where three similar aliens appear in the Galactic Senate.
The characters'... Photo: handout email Image 16 of 66 15. Steven Spielberg, despite having nothing to do with "Star Wars," has made millions of dollars off of the franchise because of a bet made with George Lucas in 1977.
Lucas, believing Spielberg's "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" would be more successful than "Star Wars," promised Spielberg 2.5 percent of his movie's profits in exchange for the same percentage from "Close Encounters." Spielberg got the better deal.
Source: Celebrity Net Worth 15. Steven Spielberg, despite having nothing to do with "Star Wars," has made millions of dollars off of the franchise because of a bet made with George Lucas in 1977.
Lucas, believing Spielberg's "Close... Photo: Evan Agostini, Associated Press Image 17 of 66 16. Mark Hamill suffered severe facial trauma and scarring during a car accident prior to filming "The Empire Strikes Back." That's why the film opens with Luke Skywalker being kidnapped and mauled by a Wampa, a "Star Wars" version of a yeti.
Source: Buzzfeed 16. Mark Hamill suffered severe facial trauma and scarring during a car accident prior to filming "The Empire Strikes Back." That's why the film opens with Luke Skywalker being kidnapped and mauled by a ... more Photo: Associated Press Image 18 of 66 17. Liam Neeson, who played Qui-Gon Jinn in "The Phantom Menace," was too tall to fit through doorways constructed for that movie's filming.
Set designers incurred an additional $150,000 in production costs to accommodate the six-foot-four actor.
Source: IMDb 17. Liam Neeson, who played Qui-Gon Jinn in "The Phantom Menace," was too tall to fit through doorways constructed for that movie's filming.
Set designers incurred an additional $150,000 in production... Image 19 of 66 18. George Lucas considered Japanese actor Toshiro Mifune, star of “Seven Samurai” and “Rashomon,” for the role of Obi-Wan Kenobi in the original trilogy.
That role instead went to Alec Guinness (right), who received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his performance.
Source: Star Wars Year by Year: A Visual Chronicle 18. George Lucas considered Japanese actor Toshiro Mifune, star of “Seven Samurai” and “Rashomon,” for the role of Obi-Wan Kenobi in the original trilogy.
That role instead went to Alec Guinness... Photo: File/Lucasfilm/Associated Press Image 20 of 66 19. George Lucas wanted Steven Spielberg to direct "Return of the Jedi." However, the Directors Guild of America prevented Spielberg from directing the film, citing feuds between Lucas, Spielberg and the guild.
Source: Grantland 19. George Lucas wanted Steven Spielberg to direct "Return of the Jedi." However, the Directors Guild of America prevented Spielberg from directing the film, citing feuds between Lucas, Spielberg and the ... more Photo: Universal/Getty Images Image 21 of 66 20. Ewan McGregor, who played Obi-Wan Kenobi in the prequel trilogy, isn’t the first in his family to be in a Star Wars movie: his uncle Denis Lawson (left) played Wedge Antilles in the original trilogy. 20. Ewan McGregor, who played Obi-Wan Kenobi in the prequel trilogy, isn’t the first in his family to be in a Star Wars movie: his uncle Denis Lawson (left) played Wedge Antilles in the original trilogy. Photo: Edwin Marcow, AP Photo/Edwin Marcow Image 22 of 66 21. Despite mixed audience response about the furry creatures, the word “Ewok” is never said out loud during “Return of the Jedi.” 21. Despite mixed audience response about the furry creatures, the word “Ewok” is never said out loud during “Return of the Jedi.” Photo: Lucasfilm Image 23 of 66 22. "Return of the Jedi," the final installment in the original trilogy, was almost named "Revenge of the Jedi" because George Lucas felt the original title was too weak. He then switched back to the original title because he believed a proper Jedi wouldn't take revenge.
Source: Empire of Dreams: The Story of the Star Wars Trilogy 22. "Return of the Jedi," the final installment in the original trilogy, was almost named "Revenge of the Jedi" because George Lucas felt the original title was too weak. He then switched back to the ... more Photo: Getty Images Image 24 of 66 23. "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan" had to change its title from "Vengeance of Khan" because the studio wanted to avoid confusion with "Revenge of the Jedi." That move proved for naught when the "Star Wars" flick's title was changed to "Return of the Jedi."
Source: iMDB 23. "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan" had to change its title from "Vengeance of Khan" because the studio wanted to avoid confusion with "Revenge of the Jedi." That move proved for naught when the "Star ... more Image 25 of 66 24. Harrison Ford wanted Han Solo to sacrifice himself and die in "Return of the Jedi," but George Lucas rejected the idea against the wishes of fellow screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan.
Source: Wired 24. Harrison Ford wanted Han Solo to sacrifice himself and die in "Return of the Jedi," but George Lucas rejected the idea against the wishes of fellow screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan.
Source: Wired Photo: Ethan Miller, Getty Images Image 26 of 66 25. The famous "No, I am your father" line from "The Empire Strikes Back" was kept secret from everyone except for Mark Hamill, George Lucas and director Irvin Kershner.
David Prowse, the actor in the Darth Vader suit, read the line: "You don't know the truth: Obi-Wan killed your father!"
Source: Sound & Vision 25. The famous "No, I am your father" line from "The Empire Strikes Back" was kept secret from everyone except for Mark Hamill, George Lucas and director Irvin Kershner.
David Prowse, the actor in the... Image 27 of 66 26. In a proposed ending to "Return of the Jedi," Luke Skywalker takes his father’s mask after he dies, puts it on and proclaims, “Now, I am Vader.”
Lucas ultimately favored a happier ending.
Source: io9 26. In a proposed ending to "Return of the Jedi," Luke Skywalker takes his father’s mask after he dies, puts it on and proclaims, “Now, I am Vader.”
Lucas ultimately favored a happier ending.
Source: io9 Image 28 of 66 27. The filming of the first "Star Wars" movie in Tunisia almost sparked an actual war: the Libyan government believed that one of the film's Sandcrawlers , positioned near the Libya-Tunisia border, was a military vehicle and threatened the Tunisian government with military movements.
Tunisian officials asked Lucas to move the model.
Source: Mic 27. The filming of the first "Star Wars" movie in Tunisia almost sparked an actual war: the Libyan government believed that one of the film's Sandcrawlers , positioned near the Libya-Tunisia border, was a ... more Photo: Uncredited, Associated Press Image 29 of 66 28. Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" caused delays on the filming of “The Empire Strikes Back” after a fire burned down an entire soundstage used to shoot the former. Kubrick, a notoriously meticulous filmmaker, took over some of the space used to shoot "Empire," taking weeks to finish his shoots.
Source: Mental Floss 28. Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" caused delays on the filming of “The Empire Strikes Back” after a fire burned down an entire soundstage used to shoot the former. Kubrick, a notoriously meticulous ... more Photo: Archive Photos, Getty Images Image 30 of 66 29. George Lucas almost didn't cast Harrison Ford as Han Solo, seeing auditions from Al Pacino, Kurt Russell (pictured) and Christopher Walken among others. However, Lucas liked the way Ford fed lines to other auditioning actors and gave him the part.
Source: Mental Floss 29. George Lucas almost didn't cast Harrison Ford as Han Solo, seeing auditions from Al Pacino, Kurt Russell (pictured) and Christopher Walken among others. However, Lucas liked the way Ford fed lines to ... more Image 31 of 66 30. David Fincher — the stylistic director of films such as "Fight Club," "Zodiac" and "Gone Girl" — was neighbors with George Lucas in San Anselmo and later worked for Lucas' visual effects company Industrial Light and Magic. While there, he worked as an assistant cameraman and matte photographer on "Return of the Jedi" and "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom."
Source: The Independent 30. David Fincher — the stylistic director of films such as "Fight Club," "Zodiac" and "Gone Girl" — was neighbors with George Lucas in San Anselmo and later worked for Lucas' visual effects company ... more Photo: 20TH CENTURY FOX Image 32 of 66 Scroll through the slideshow for all of the latest images from "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."

Abrams (top center right) at the cast read-through of Star Wars: Episode VII at Pinewood Studios with (clockwise from right) Harrison Ford, Daisy Ridley, Carrie Fisher, Peter Mayhew, Producer Bryan Burk, Lucasfilm President and Producer Kathleen Kennedy, Domhnall Gleeson, Anthony Daniels, Mark Hamill, Andy Serkis, Oscar Isaac, John Boyega, Adam Driver and Writer Lawrence Kasdan. Writer/Director/Producer J.J. Abrams (top center right) at the cast read-through of Star Wars: Episode VII at Pinewood Studios with (clockwise from right) Harrison Ford, Daisy Ridley, Carrie Fisher, Peter ... more Image 66 of 66 Trailer, tickets for 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' to be released today 1 / 66 Back to Gallery Hardcore "Star Wars" nerds will have to watch, sigh, a football game if they want to be the first to glimpse never-before-seen tidbits from that galaxy far, far away.
The full trailer for the highly-anticipated movie "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" will drop during halftime of the New York Giants and Philadelphia Eagles game at 7:30 p.m. Central Standard Time on ESPN — a subsidiary of Disney, parent company of Lucasfilm, the film's production company.
Tickets for the movie, to be released Dec. 18, will go on sale shortly after, Lucasfilm announced Sunday .
The company also released the first poster for the series' seventh film, set 30 years after the events of "Return of the Jedi."
Check out the new official poster! Tune in to @ESPN ’s Monday Night Football for a new look at #TheForceAwakens . pic.twitter.com/NTRWLlVyID
— Star Wars (@starwars) October 18, 2015 Lucasfilm, acquired by Disney in 2012 for $4 billion, has kept a tight lid on the new film's plot, making Monday's trailer the largest look at the movie to date.
The company released the first 90-second teaser in November 2014, following up with another 90-second teaser in April, a three-and-a-half minute behind-the-scenes video at San Diego Comic Con in July and a brief Instagram teaser in August — leaving fans jonesing for story details and images from the new film.
But, the minimal teases have gone pretty far in terms of building hype: the second trailer alone has garnered more than 63 million views on YouTube since its release.
RELATED: Princess Leia bikini from 'Star Wars' fetches nearly $100,000 at auction
"The Force Awakens" signifies a number of "firsts" for the film series: it's the first "Star Wars" film since Disney acquired Lucasfilm in 2012; the first since 2005's "Revenge of the Sith," the conclusion to a divisive set of prequel films; and, perhaps most importantly, the first to be made without series creator George Lucas in a major production role.
Lucasfilm, now under the stewardship of film producer Kathleen Kennedy, seemingly aped the franchise model employed by fellow Disney property Marvel, opening the faucet for a new "Star Wars" trilogy to be concluded in 2019 along with a series of stand-alone films exploring stories within the universe but outside of the main chronology.
RELATED: Giant California $14.9 million mansion with a Star Wars-themed bedroom
The new film combines new cast members — including Boyega, Driver, Daisy Ridley, Oscar Isaac, Gwendoline Christie and Lupita Nyong'o among others — with returning actors from the original "Star Wars" trilogy, including Hamill, Ford and Carrie Fisher.
Director J.J. Abrams — who previously helmed the 2009 film "Star Trek" and its 2013 sequel "Star Trek Into Darkness" — co-wrote the screenplay with Lawrence Kasdan, who helped pen "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Return of the Jedi."
Composer John Williams will also return to orchestrate the series' iconic musical score.
RELATED: Photographer snaps photo of 'Han Cholo,' 'Loca Leia' in 'Star Wars' cosplay at Long Beach Comic Con
Box office predictions vary for "The Force Awakens," with many speculating that it could challenge James Cameron's 2009 film "Avatar" for the title of highest-grossing film of all time without adjusting for inflation.
That film made more than $2.7 billion worldwide by the end of its theatrical run, according to Box Office Mojo .
A "realistic" prediction from Forbes predicts the new film will likely make between $1.3 billion and $1.6 billion worldwide.
"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" will open for U.S. audiences on Dec. 18, though screenings of the film are expected to begin the evening of Dec. 17.
Scroll through the above slideshow to test your "Star Wars" knowledge and treat yourself with the latest images from the upcoming film.
